mainContent.text:
1.3 Edgar Allan Poe - "The Cask of Amontillado"

        Completion requirements
        



The Gothic Short Story

Poe uses many Gothic elements to create this masterpiece of the macabre.  First, he uses a superb narrator, Montressor, who shows vast intelligence, cunning, and manipulation.  His plan of revenge is clearly
    premeditated, but he never divulges the offense Fortunado committed against him and his family, providing no clear motive. 
Secondly, Poe adds suspense through setting: the ancient Italian city, the festival of Carnival, which begins with Mardi Gras ("Fat Tuesday"), the catacombs, the niter covering the walls, the niche, chain and stone wall. 
    Most Gothic horror stories are set in haunted houses; here, we have an underground network of them: the old burial grounds beneath the city instill fear in the soul of any in Christendom.
Poe's primary device used to create suspense is foreshadowing.  Montressor reveals his coat of arms to Fortunado, the snake biting the heal that steps on it--clear symbols of revenge.  He shows the trowel to
    him and gives him a phony Masonic gesture.  And then there's the amontillado, one of the greatest red herrings in literature.
Because "The Cask of Amontillado" is a frame story (a story whose primary action is told in flashback), the ending of the inner story of revenge is never in doubt.  We know Fortundo is being
    lured to his doom through Poe's use of masterful dramatic irony (when the audience knows what will happen before Fortunato).  But, the motive for the murder is never given, so the outer story of confession
    seems uncharacteristically hollow and open-ended.  Gothic narrators usually relish in how fitting the revenge is to the original crime, but not Montressor.  His madness is like the great villains (like "the Joker"),
    as he is an agent of inexplicable chaos.  

Assignment:  Read "The Cask of Amontillado" by Edgar Allan Poe.
